item.title: Iraqis Protest Electricity Shortage During Heat Wave
item.description: One of the country’s largest recent grass-roots protests shut down traffic in Baghdad on Friday night, and more protests took place Saturday in southern Iraq.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD

item.title: Palestinian Teenager Is Fatally Shot While Protesting Deadly Arson Attack
item.description: An Israeli military spokeswoman said soldiers had fired “in response to immediate danger” after a firebomb was hurled at them.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID

item.title: Tibetan Who Called for Dalai Lama’s Return Is Said to Be Freed From Chinese Prison
item.description: Runggye Adak was jailed for eight years after calling for the spiritual leader’s return to Tibet in a speech at a major festival.
item.dc:creator: EDWARD WONG

item.title: New Meningitis Strain in Africa Brings Call for More Vaccines
item.description: An international consortium is seeking five million doses of the vaccine against Type C meningitis and says they must arrive by January to be effective.
item.dc:creator: DONALD G. McNEIL Jr.
item.media:description: Somali mothers waiting in line in Mogadishu to have their babies vaccinated against meningitis and other diseases in 2013. Meningitis C infections are on the rise across Africa.

item.title: World Briefing: Food Program Gets Emergency Cash
item.description: The anti-hunger agency of the United Nations said that it had averted a suspension of aid to 440,000 Syrian refugees in Jordan after the United States gave $65 million.
item.dc:creator: RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: World Briefing: Lawmakers on Azerbaijan Trip Cleared
item.description: The House Ethics Committee announced that it had cleared 10 lawmakers and 32 House employees of any wrongdoing associated with a trip to Azerbaijan.
item.dc:creator: ERIC LIPTON

item.title: Rivals of ISIS Attack U.S.-Backed Syrian Rebel Group
item.description: The members trained by the United States to take on the Islamic State found themselves fighting off an attack from another Islamist faction.
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
item.dc:creator: ANNE BARNARD and ERIC SCHMITT

item.title: U.S. Decides to Retaliate Against China’s Hacking
item.description: The Obama administration decided a response was needed after the Chinese stole data on 20 million Americans from the Office of Personnel Management.
item.category: United States Defense and Military Forces
item.dc:creator: DAVID E. SANGER

item.title: Open Source: Indian Rapper Calls Out Unilever to a Nicki Minaj Beat
item.description: For the song, “Kodaikanal Won’t,” Sofia Ashraf borrowed the tune to “Anaconda,” but crafted entirely new lyrics.
item.dc:creator: ROBERT MACKEY

item.title: Founder of Haqqani Network Is Long Dead, Aide Says
item.description: The death of Jalaluddin Haqqani in 2014 was reported days after the Taliban’s overall leader was confirmed to have died more than two years ago.
item.dc:creator: MATTHEW ROSENBERG and IHSANULLAH TIPU MEHSUD

item.title: Taliban Pick New Chief and 2 Hard-Line Deputies
item.description: The move elevated the standing of the extremist Haqqani faction, but was rejected by the late leader Mullah Omar’s son, threatening a split within the group.
item.dc:creator: TAIMOOR SHAH and ROD NORDLAND

item.title: Plane Debris Is Probably From Flight 370, Australians Say
item.description: Two senior officials cautioned that final confirmation about the object found on a remote French island could come only from the French or Malaysian authorities.
item.dc:creator: MICHELLE INNIS
item.media:description: Workers searched the beach for possible debris near where part of an airplane was found washed up on the island of Reunion on Friday.

item.title: Jewish Arsonists Suspected in West Bank Attack That Killed Palestinian Toddler
item.description: The attack was branded as terrorism by Israeli and Palestinian politicians, and shocked consciences on both sides of the simmering conflict.
item.dc:creator: DIAA HADID and JODI RUDOREN
item.media:description: Mourners buried the remains of 18-month-old Ali Saad Dawabsheh in the West Bank village of Duma on Friday.

item.title: Inquiry Into Litvinenko Poisoning Ends With a Nugget of Debris
item.description: The lawyer for the widow of the former K.G.B. officer said Vladimir Putin must have approved the use of a radioactive toxin traced to a suspect’s London hotel room.
item.dc:creator: ALAN COWELL
item.media:description: Marina Litvinenko, the widow of Alexander V. Litvinenko, outside the High Court in London after the inquiry into her husband's death ended on Friday.

item.title: At War Blog: Reactions to Article About Gender Integration in the Marine Corps
item.description: The Times asked readers what they thought of Lt. Col. Kate Germano’s article where she argued for equal standards and expectations of training for Marines, whether male or female.
item.dc:creator: ROCHELLE OLIVER and SHREEYA SINHA
item.media:description: Lt. Col. Kate Germano, who took command of the Marine Corps’ all-women boot camp, was . The Corps said her Marines had been mistreated; she said her ability to command had been undermined.

item.title: Britain and France Point Fingers as Migrant Crisis Becomes a Political One
item.description: The British are blaming the French, the French are blaming the British, and both are blaming the European Union for what they call an incoherent policy.
item.dc:creator: STEVEN ERLANGER and KIMIKO DE FREYTAS-TAMURA
item.media:description: Drivers waited next to their parked trucks on the M20 highway leading to the Channel Tunnel terminal. More than 4,500 vehicles are stuck along the route.

item.title: France Will Compensate Russia for Canceling Arms Deal, Kremlin Aide Says
item.description: France has agreed to pay Russia compensation for refusing to deliver two helicopter carrier ships after sanctions were imposed on Russia over its annexation of Crimea.
item.dc:creator: SABRINA TAVERNISE

item.title: Zimbabwe Official Urges Extradition of Dentist Who Killed Cecil the Lion
item.description: Oppah Muchinguri, the environment minister, said Dr. Walter J. Palmer, a dentist and big-game hunter from Minnesota, had broken Zimbabwe’s laws.
item.dc:creator: DAN BILEFSKY
item.media:description: The killing of Cecil, who was the subject of research at the University of Oxford, has spurred global outrage on social media and beyond, and forced Dr. Walter J. Palmer into hiding.

item.title: Myanmar Declares Disaster Zones to Deal With Dire Flooding
item.description: Myanmar’s president said several regions of the country are disaster zones, as more heavy rains are expected.
item.dc:creator: THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: A girl sold food on Friday in Rangoon, Myanmar, where flooding and landslides have left at least 20 people dead this month.

item.title: Philippines’ President Endorses Mar Roxas as Successor
item.description: President Benigno S. Aquino III praised Mr. Roxas, his interior secretary, as the candidate most likely to carry on his anticorruption efforts.
item.dc:creator: FLOYD WHALEY
